item.title: Cloudflare, CrowdStrike, and Ping Identity launch the Critical Infrastructure Defense Project
item.description: Today, Cloudflare is launching the Critical Infrastructure Defense Project. The Project was born out of conversations with cybersecurity and government experts concerned about potential retaliation to the sanctions that resulted from the Russian invasion of Ukraine
item.author: (Matthew Prince)

item.title: Adding feature flags to an ASP.NET Core app
item.description: This post is about Adding feature flags to an ASP.NET Core app.Feature flags (also known as feature toggles or feature switches) are a software development technique that turns certain functionality on and off during runtime, without deploying new code. In this post we will discuss about flags using appsettings.json file. I am using an ASP.NET Core MVC project, you can do it for any .NET Core project like Razor Web Apps, or Web APIs.
item.author: (Anuraj)

item.title: Introduction to Unit Testing With NUnit in C# - Code Maze
item.description: In this article, we are going to talk about the NUnit testing framework that we can use to write tests in our C# applications.

item.title: Steps we've taken around Cloudflare's services in Ukraine, Belarus, and Russia
item.description: At Cloudflare, we've watched in horror the Russian invasion of Ukraine. As the possibility of war looked more likely, we began to carefully monitor the situation on the ground, with the goal of keeping our employees, our customers, and our network safe

item.title: Microsoft DDoS protection response guide
item.description: Receiving Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack threats? This guide provides an overview of what Microsoft provides at the platform level, information on recent mitigations, and best practices.

item.title: Windows Package Manager 1.2
item.description: We’ve been busy improving the Windows Package Manager. Today I have the pleasure of announcing the availability of Windows Package Manager 1.2. It has been released to the Microsoft Store as an automatic update to the “App Installer” this morning if you’re running Windows 10 (1809+) or Windows 11.
item.author: (Demitrius Nelon)

item.title: PowerShell and OpenSSH team investments for 2022
item.description: It’s time to discuss the team investments for 2022. For some areas we’ll be completing work we’ve already started, and in others we’ll be beginning on new projects. Executive Order on Cybersecurity One of the areas we’ve already spent significant effort on is adhering to the Executive Order on Cybersecurity.

item.title: Escaping privileged containers for fun
item.description: Despite the fact that it is not a 'real' vulnerability, escaping privileged Docker containers is nevertheless pretty funny. item.title: Building a generate routes function using Terraform test
item.description: Welcome to the next episode of thinking out loud to route in the cloud with style. Earlier this season we abstracted a TGW Centralized Router. Part of it’s responsibility is to manage routes between Tiered VPCs within a single region. Looking forward, it would be nice to route between many TGW Centralized Routers but cross region with some kind of TGW Super Router abstraction. I think it should roughly look like:
